data.title: Breaking function calls into multiple lines silently breaks builds
data.body:
My system: http://pasted.co/ca4970b9
(with kernel 4.8)
Using Godot 2.1 Stable

If you break a function call into multiple calls it works flawlessly in the editor, with no runtime problems or syntax errors whatsoever.
```
	tween.interpolate_property(
		self,
		"transform/pos",
		get_pos(),
		ev.pos,
		0.1,
		Tween.TRANS_LINEAR,
		Tween.EASE_IN_OUT)
```

Still, if one tries to export the project with such a call, the export (apparently) completes successfully.

But as soon as one tries to execute such build, it fails to execute (crashes completely) or simply renders that specific script broken.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2046959/23829075/227d590c-06c5-11e7-84b3-f6df3617cc1b.png)

Calling functions without breaking them in several lines (or using the \ character to do so) works fine on both the editor and the exported builds.

[Issue.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/836296/Issue.zip)

data.title: get_rotation() returns confusing euler angles
data.body:
In Godot 2.1

I set the rotation of a Camera to `(0, 180, 0)` in the editor.
But if I print `get_rotation()` in `_ready()`, I get `(-3.141593, -0, -3.141593)`, which in degrees is `(-180, 0, -180)`.
EDIT: if I close and repoen the scene, the inspector now shows `(-180, 0, -180)` in the rotation field as well.

I understand the angles technically represent the same orientation, however I didn't expected that, and I'm confused about how to initialize my FPS lookat now.

I have a [camera script](https://github.com/Zylann/voxelgame/blob/master/project/debug_camera.gd#L75) that has its own `yaw` and `pitch` (the latter being clamped), and these need to represent the initial rotation of the camera when the game starts, and it obviously won't work given the funky values `get_rotation()` returns.

Is there a way to initialize the rotations properly? Did this change in 3.0? Should I rewrite my script?

Edit: my current shitty workaround:
```gdscript
	# Nope, can't do this
	#_yaw = get_rotation().y

	var v = get_transform().basis.xform(Vector3(1,0,0))
	if v.z <= 0:
		_yaw = rad2deg(acos(v.x))
	elif v.z > 0:
		_yaw = -rad2deg(acos(v.x))
```

data.title: Improve directional shadow filtering by using linear interpolation
data.body:
Example project: [directional_light.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/835774/directional_light.zip) (use Godot Git master to open it; run it, then use WASD or arrow keys and the mouse to fly around)

___

This fixes directional shadows looking blocky. There doesn't seem to be any noticeable performance difference. Note that moving shadows still have some artifacts, this can be fixed by using multisampling or supersampling (at a performance cost).

**Platforms to test before merging:**

- [x] AMD on Linux
- [ ] AMD on macOS
- [x] AMD on Windows
- [x] Intel on Linux
- [ ] Intel on macOS
- [ ] Intel on Windows
- [x] NVIDIA on Linux
- [ ] NVIDIA on macOS
- [x] NVIDIA on Windows
- [ ] Android
- [ ] iOS
- [ ] WebAssembly

Example screenshot of new shadows:

![screenshot_20170310_222845](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/180032/23822934/81ce111c-0657-11e7-8cad-254cafda51b8.png)

Please test locally.

data.title: On start, screen does not redraw after Xmonad resizes.
data.body:
<!--
README: Incompatibilities and broken features in the current master branch / 3.0-alpha
are known and expected due to important refactoring work, so no need to report them for now. Thanks!
-->

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Editor running on Linux (Arch or Ubuntu) in the Xmonad tiling window manager.


**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When the editor is launched in Xmonad, a tiling window manager, the screen is drawn small even though the workspace is increased to fill available screen area.  Moving the window, or changing the tiling configuration causes a redraw and all is well.  The editor (or project manager) responds to mouse clicks on the new size, not on the drawn size.  Clearly, all that is needed is a later (repeat?) redraw, but I wouldn't know where to look in the code.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Launch the editor in Xmonad tiling window manager (maybe other tilers also problematic?)

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
n/a

data.title: Sprite3D can't be one-sided
data.body: `Sprite3D` nodes have a backface, they're two-sided. Unfortunately, you can't disable this if you want to, say, have a different sprite for the reverse. This is easy enough to work around by using a `Quad` instead, but a simple “One-sided” or “No backface” checkbox would be simpler.

data.title: GDScript: inconsistencies in constants
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1.x, probably 3.0 as well


**Issue description:**
GDScript recognition of constants is still not universal. There are certain cases that I think it should handle:

You can do this:
```
# Built-in functions by themselves work
const a = deg2rad(90.0)

# Some built-ins work with a const argument although not a literal
const b = sin(a) 

# Involvement of built-ins in binary operators work with a literal argument
const c = sin(1.57) + cos(1.57)
```

But you can't do any of these:
```
# Composition of built-in functions fails
const d = sin(deg2rad(90.0))

# Certain built-ins fail with a non-literal argument (though constant))
const e = 32
const f = pow(2, e)

# Involvement of built-ins in binary operators don't work with a non-literal constant argument
const g = 3.14
const h = sin(1.57) + cos(g)
```

I think all these non-working cases fit the const world so it would be nice for GDScript to generalize it's handling of constants-

data.title: Control set_pos -> set_position
data.body:
Since Node2D set_pos() has changed to set_position() in 3.0 I think Control set_pos() should also be renamed to keep everything consistent.

 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4741886/23815773/d4c091d8-05e9-11e7-9937-d5156779e40b.png)


![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4741886/23815744/ba44d724-05e9-11e7-9869-3418a3bde340.png)

https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/5dbf1809c6e3e905b94b8764e99491e608122261/core/math/math_2d.h#L207
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/5dbf1809c6e3e905b94b8764e99491e608122261/scene/gui/control.cpp#L60

See also that Node2d has a set_rotation_in_degrees(value) and set_rotation(value)
Control has only set_rotation(radians).

data.title: Normal map with unrotated camera will make a quad black
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Tested in Godot 2.1.2 and Godot 3. Both display the same issue

**Issue description:**
Setting a normal map on a quad, with the camera facing straight at it, will show only a black quad. In the editor everything looks fine, but the problem appears when running the game.

Rotating the camera even a tiny bit will solve the issue. Which suggests to me that when something is 0, something breaks :p

**Link to minimal example project:**

Reported in Q&A with sample project: https://godotengine.org/qa/13060/cannot-normal-mapping-fixedmaterial-screenshots-project

data.title: GDScript, indentation and inline blocks not working well together
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch linux. Godot 2.1, 2.2, and most likely master too

**Issue description:**
When using `for` with an inline `if` body, GDScript fails to understand that it can have just one level of indentation afterwards.
```gdscript
for i in range(0, 100): if can_use(i):
	use(i) # One tab here
```
The above code fails with:
```
Parser Error: Expected intended block after 'if'
```
While this works correctly:
```gdscript
for i in range(0, 100): if can_use(i):
		use(i) # Two tabs here
```

**Steps to reproduce:**
Follow description around, or just run (mind the tabs):
```gdscript
for i in range(0, 100): if i % 2 or i % 3:
		print(i, " is divisible by either 2 or 3 (you knew, didn't ya?)")
for i in range(0, 100): if i % 7 or i % 9:
	print(i, " is divisible by either 7 or 9")
```

**Link to minimal example project:**
You don't really need one, but I can produce it on-demand.

data.title: [TRACKER] 3.0 Import system issues
data.body:
This is a tracker issue for the import system bugs, so they don't go unnoticed. (some of them might need to be retested for 3.0)

- [x] #3872 - Looping samples is a bit unintuitive currently (closed as obsolete)
- [x] #4816 - Imported materials' colors are not corrected
- [ ] #5640 - .csv chokes on CRLF/windows-1251
- [ ] #5678 - AtlasTexture hot-reloading goes into a reimport loop
- [ ] #5823 - Imported navmeshes aren't imported into Navigation nodes
- [x] #5990 - (probably invalid) Custom plugins used for importing get stuck into reimport loop sometimes
- [x] #6509 - PNG flags might need to be tristate - on/off/default, or be always saved
- [x] #7175 - Post-import scripts are not executed properly
- [x] #7755 - Audio import errors out on 96KHz samples
- [x] #8075 - .dae not applying material on import
- [x] #9267 - Normal Maps do not import correctly
- [ ] #9939 - Normals artifacting issue on collada exported models
- [ ] #10017 - Reimport 3D models doesn't update assets in opened scene
- [x] #10038 - Deleting an asset/resource should remove imports & related files as well 
- [ ] #10070 - Importing some textures crashes Godot 3
- [ ] #10130 - glTF importer fails to import models with armatures
- [ ] #10742 - gltf importer fails to import textures
- [ ] #10780 - glTF import crashes when importing models with cameras

And here are some discussions about what the new system might have:

- [ ] #7408 - Where it all started
- [ ] #4826 - .svg vector graphics import
- [ ] #6339 - Support non-csv translation formats
- [ ] #7883 - .blend files direct import (via assimp)
- [x] #7952 - glTF format import (export?)

data.title: UI: ability to add multiple child nodes in single click
data.body:
Usage:
When FOCUS on tree node, multiple nodes can be selected using the
[space] key . Hodling [ctrl] on single mouse click add to current
selection. [shift] mouse click also work for grouped selection.
If no node selected, [Create] button is desabled.

Nota:
* multiple node selection not active with search node feature.
* Multiselect mode is disabled for other than node creation.

data.body:
Operating system or device - Godot version:
Godot - 2.1 or 2.0/ windows 7

Issue description:
I put some 2d Rigidbodies with "character" mode in scene, they have no any forces applied to them, but debugger show this objects as "active" (with "rigid" mode they sleep and become non active just fine)

data.title: Added 'get_rpc_id' method to SceneTree.
data.body: Provides one of the methods discussed here #7853 and #7362 to validate the ID of a peer calling an RPC function.

data.title: Raw Mouse Input
data.body:
Godot for Windows, Linux and MacOS.

`InputEventMouseMotion.relative_x`, `relative_y` and `relative_pos` provide the relative movement of the mouse processed by the Operating System. In other words, the OS read the raw input from the mouse, processes it (with sensitivity change, acceleration, and so on), and then the processed value is read from Godot mouse input api.

In Windows, for example, if you increase the mouse sensitivity setting in Control Panel, the values in Godot's `InputEventMouseMotion` is also amplified.

I'd like to be able to get the raw mouse movement data, without the OS processing. This is widely used in first person shooter games, such as CS, TF and OW. It is important when the gameplay requires accurate mouse tracking, and OS filters and biases are undesirable. The game may end up doing its own processing in the raw data, but its mechanics will be consistent across different OSes and OS settings.

data.title: Optimize out OS.is_debug_build(), implement debug_assert()
data.body:
# A) Optimizing out `OS.is_debug_build()`

I tend to put assertions here and there in my GDScripts. Sometimes just not a plain assert but a call to a more complex routine to check if certain preconditions are met:

```
func _ready():
    if OS.is_debug_build():
        debug_check_nodes_z():
```

Do you think that letting the compiler handle ' OS.is_debug_build()'  as a constant could provide some benefit in terms of performance or something?

# B) Implementing `debug_assert()`

Sometimes I don't want a certain assert to crash the game if failed. In case it's checking about something that should be some way but is not critical, I have to write::

```
if OS.is_debug_build():
    assert(...)
```

What do yoy think about adding a `debug_assert()` that gets checked only on debug builds?

data.title: Avoid connecting signal to nonexistent methods when replacing nodes
data.body:
Fixes #6602 (Only the first part)

I made it print an error once instead of silently skipping it to be consistent, since that's what happens if you try to connect a nonexisting signal when replacing nodes, e.g: Control with signal `focus_enter ` to Node. It's also better for debugging purposes, WDYT?

data.title: Core motion for Godot 2.x (based on PR 7127)
data.body:
Submitting the changes of PR #7127 but for the Godot 2.1 branch.

There is a test godot project here:
https://github.com/BastiaanOlij/TestCoreMotion
that demonstrates this functionality. Note that someone still needs to make the changes to Android to expose the gravity vector which is used to calculate the orientation of the device.

If you combine this with PR #7778 you've got all the ingredients to make a cardboard type iPhone application.

data.title: Add classes for random number generation (RNG)
data.body:
This is perhaps more a request for comments than a real pull request. I still have some doubts about how to do things the Godot way (see my questions below), but overall this is the design I'd personally like to see in the engine.

It is used like this:

```gdscript
var rng = RandPCG32.new()   # Or another RNG class, like Xoroshiro128Plus
rng.seed(1234)  # rng.randomize() also exists

n = rng.uniform_float(-1.0, 2.0) # uniform in interval [-1.0, 2.0]
n = rng.uniform_int(1, 6) # six-sided die
n = rng.boolean(0.1)  # 10% of chance of being true
n = rng.normal(-3.0, 2.0)  # Gaussian, mean = -3, std. deviation = 2.0
n = rng.exponential(2.0) # from exponential distribution with mean = 2.0
```

I believe the current random number generation facilities in Godot are good for simple use cases (and I'd say that they should remain available), but more "interesting" RNG usage needs something new. I had three main goals in mind:

1) Add a few more useful distributions beyond uniform.

2) Let the user create separate instances of the RNG algorithm, in order to generate different independent sequences (pretty useful for procedural generation of content).

3) Allow users to be sure that they can create reproducible pseudorandom sequences even between Godot releases.

The biggest open points and questions I still have are:

* Do you consider this design in general good for Godot?
   * One sub-question here: What about providing multiple RNG algorithms as I did? I think that choosing a RNG is a trade-off, so I like the idea of providing the alternatives and letting the user chose one. Providing one single `Rand` class would be simpler (which is good), but if we ever decide to replace the one algorithm with something else, my point 3 above is not achieved. And I like RNG algorithms, so my opinion *is* biassed :-)
* How to add tests for this? I am currently using a Godot project (https://github.com/lmbarros/GodotRandTest/ -- it is currently quite ugly, BTW) that calls my methods from GDScript and checks if the results are OK. However, in order to be able to make these tests, I was required to expose `Rand::random()` to GDScript, which otherwise I wouldn't.
* Sometimes it is useful to save the RNG state with a saved game (to avoid the save-reload-and-try-again "cheat"). I am a Godot beginner, so I don't know if there is any support or standard way for doing serialization or save games.
* The newer versions of the C++ standard have implementations of various RNG algorithms and random distributions. For some reason that beyond my own understanding I haven't used them here. Is the usage of these newer parts of the C++ standard library allowed or encouraged in Godot?
* I implemented this on Linux and didn't test anywhere else. There is nothing platform-specific here, but we may need to tweak the implementation a bit to make it compile everywhere.
 
----

Six RNG algorithms are provided: PCG32, Xoroshiro128+, two variations of
Mersenne Twister (MT19937 and MT19937-64), SplitMix64 and a simple LCG.
Different random distributions are provided: uniform (for integers and
floats), normal (Gaussian), exponential and Bernoulli (for generating
Booleans).

All algorithms and distributions are usable from GDScript.

The base `Rand` class contains the interface that must be implemented by
all RNG algorithms and the implementation of the different
distributions. Subclasses that implement each of the actual RNG
algorithms inherit the distributions. This way, new algorithms and new
distributions can be easily added, and every algorithm can be used with
every distribution.
